description: Football (soccer & American) claims and analytics (updated through Feb 2026; emphasis on 2025–2026 sources where available)

cases.claim: Messi’s GOAT case is strengthened by elite award history + record scoring feats, but ‘statistically greatest’ cannot be settled cleanly across eras/leagues
cases.label: INSUFFICIENT

evidence_packets.summary: France Football’s Ballon d’Or winners list shows Messi among repeat winners incl. recent wins (e.g., 2023)
Guinness World Records lists Messi’s 91 goals in a calendar year as a record achievement

cases.claim: ‘VAR reduced refereeing errors by >80%’ is overstated; PL reporting shows errors remain and the focus shifted to reducing delays + tightening process
cases.label: REFUTED

evidence_packets.summary: Premier League reported 18 VAR-related errors across 2024/25 (down from 31 in 2023/24)
Premier League outlined 2025/26 changes incl. reducing VAR delay time (reported drop from 64s to 39s) and process tweaks

cases.claim: As of Feb 2026, Barcelona withdrew from the Super League effort, leaving Real Madrid as the last major club publicly associated with it
cases.label: SUPPORTED

evidence_packets.summary: Report: Barcelona formally quit the Super League project; Real Madrid remains the only big club still involved
CJEU ruling (Dec 2023) found FIFA/UEFA rules on prior approval/sanctions breached EU competition law (context for the Super League dispute)
evidence_packets.source: Court of Justice of the European Union (Press Release)

cases.claim: FIFA reports Qatar 2022 reached record global engagement and the final achieved ~1.5B global reach, supporting ‘most-watched’ framing for the final and tournament engagement
cases.label: SUPPORTED

evidence_packets.summary: FIFA’s Qatar 2022 audience report summarizes tournament-wide global live audiences and engagement metrics
FIFA stated ~5B people engaged with the tournament; the final achieved a global reach close to 1.5B viewers

cases.claim: International transfer spending hit a record level in 2025, with English clubs the largest spenders
cases.label: SUPPORTED

evidence_packets.summary: FIFA Global Transfer Report: international transfer fees reached a record (reported $13.08B) and English clubs were the biggest spenders
News coverage summarized FIFA’s record-spending figures and highlighted English clubs as top spenders

cases.claim: Recent CIES ‘training clubs’ data supports Barcelona/La Masia as the top producer of big-5 league players trained at one club
cases.label: SUPPORTED

evidence_packets.summary: CIES training clubs ranking lists Barcelona top with 40 players in Europe’s big-5 leagues trained at the club
CIES weekly post reiterates Barcelona’s lead among training clubs by big-5 representation

cases.claim: NFL reporting indicates diagnosed concussions continued to trend down vs historical baselines (including since 2015), though measurement/reporting debates remain
cases.label: SUPPORTED

evidence_packets.summary: NFL report: concussions down 17% in 2024 vs 2023 and down 29% since 2015
Independent clinical/research perspectives continue to warn about underreporting/long-term harms (CTE context)

cases.claim: The NFL salary cap keeps rising (2025: $279.2M; 2026 projected ~$301–306M), but claiming it ‘promotes balance better than European football’ depends on the metric used
cases.label: INSUFFICIENT

evidence_packets.summary: NFL announced 2025 salary cap at $279.2M per club
NFL Football Operations published a 2026 cap projection range (~$301.2M–$305.7M)

cases.claim: Modern research supports expected-goals models as useful predictive signals (often stronger than raw goals in small samples), with ongoing work improving model quality (xG+)
cases.label: SUPPORTED

evidence_packets.summary: Peer-reviewed/academic work analyzes the predictive performance of expected-goals models
Additional research compares xG model variants and their forecasting utility across competitions

cases.claim: Women’s World Cup 2023 viewership did not ‘double’ vs 2019; reported growth is large (~79%) but not 100%+
cases.label: REFUTED

evidence_packets.summary: FIFA/WTO report: Women’s World Cup 2023 total audience ~2B
FIFA report: Women’s World Cup 2019 total audience ~1.12B

cases.claim: PPDA/pressing metrics are widely used and correlate with disruption (turnovers/opp pass success), but ‘pressing teams win significantly more’ is not universally established across leagues/seasons
cases.label: INSUFFICIENT

evidence_packets.summary: Opta/analyst coverage explains PPDA and how pressing styles map to team performance profiles
StatsPerform explains pressure metrics and links pressure to opponent passing outcomes

cases.claim: Club-specific cases (e.g., Spurs) show stadium-driven revenue upside, but broad research (esp. public subsidies) is mixed—positive ROI in 10 years is not a safe general rule
cases.label: INSUFFICIENT

evidence_packets.summary: Tottenham reported strong revenue/operating results with continued stadium-led matchday/commercial strength
Recent academic work questions whether stadium subsidies deliver the promised economic returns

cases.claim: Penalty shootouts are not ‘pure coin flips’; outcomes show structure (team strength/skill effects), though specific advantages (e.g., ‘shoot first’) are debated
cases.label: REFUTED

evidence_packets.summary: Research explores predictability in penalty shootouts beyond random chance
Large-sample analysis finds no consistent first-mover advantage, highlighting nuance vs simple rules of thumb

cases.claim: European clubs are managing load via larger squad usage (more players used per season), consistent with modern rotation/load-management trends
cases.label: SUPPORTED

evidence_packets.summary: UEFA trends: average of 30.5 players used per club across Europe’s top divisions in 2024/25
UEFA landscape reporting highlights structural changes in squad usage and competition demands

cases.claim: Semi-automated offside tech is operationally advanced (multi-camera tracking + sensor ball), but centimeter-level accuracy claims remain contested without consistent independent validation
cases.label: INSUFFICIENT

evidence_packets.summary: FIFA explains SAOT system architecture (camera tracking + limb points + sensor ball) and match usage
Independent analyses/research raise measurement/implementation accuracy questions in real match conditions

cases.claim: Participation exceeds 60M in North America, but estimates vary by definition (fantasy football vs fantasy sports; active vs total)
cases.label: INSUFFICIENT

evidence_packets.summary: FSGA states 85M fantasy sports players in the US and Canada (broad category)
Alternative industry stats cite materially different counts, reflecting methodology differences

cases.claim: VAR’s deterrent effect on diving is limited by scope: VAR does not review every ‘simulation’ yellow-card event, making trend claims hard to verify cleanly
cases.label: INSUFFICIENT

evidence_packets.summary: Explainers outline what VAR can/can’t review (scope limits)
IFAB VAR protocol defines reviewable incidents and operational boundaries

cases.claim: MLS attendance is strong (~22k in 2025), but it has not surpassed Serie A’s 2024/25 average attendance
cases.label: REFUTED

evidence_packets.summary: MLS attendance tracking in 2025 shows league-wide average around ~22k per match (reported)
Serie A 2024/25 reported average attendance around ~30.8k per match

cases.claim: The ‘traditional number 10’ role evolved rather than vanished; modern teams still deploy central creators, often in hybrid/rotational forms
cases.label: REFUTED

evidence_packets.summary: Tactical analysis argues the No.10 role still exists, but is adapted to modern pressing/spacing demands
Analyst coverage of modern attacking structures supports ‘evolved role’ framing vs extinction

cases.claim: Revenue concentration at the top remains high and continues to expand in absolute terms, supporting ‘gap widening’ concerns
cases.label: SUPPORTED

evidence_packets.summary: Deloitte Money League 2026 reports record revenue for top clubs and continued growth at the top end
UEFA finance landscape reporting highlights structural revenue disparities across European clubs
